It is caused by the round-trip. Switching from class-based dispatch to URN-based dispatch didn't actually incur a dependency on the protos themselves. Should be just adding this to the pom:

```xml
  <dependency>
    <groupId>org.apache.beam</groupId>
    <artifactId>beam-model-pipeline</artifactId>
  </dependency>
```
Hmm, okay, simpler question: did your pipeline start working correctly after this change? :)

One more question: for Samza, it'll be nice we know the partitions of a Unbounded/Bounded source if it is partitioned, e.g Kafka. With this I can split a source by its partition count by default and each partition will be a split. This is how Samza itself works today by default, so it's consistent with the current model. Seems right now I don't see such metadata being exposed in the general UnboundedSource/BoundedSource.
@rangadi any comment on this? I think that the way it works it that the source itself will split into the default number. Dataflow used to do this during translation, which was not a great thing. Now splittable DoFn makes it necessary to do it dynamically. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4340)*

Previously, kennknowles (Kenn Knowles) wroteâ€¦
@rangadi any comment on this? I think that the way it works it that the source itself will split into the default number. Dataflow used to do this during translation, which was not a great thing. Now splittable DoFn makes it necessary to do it dynamically.
The UnboundedSource interface is somewhat similar to hadoop. split() method passes in 'desiredNumSplits' which is a hint from the runner to the source. The source can try to obey or return any number splits that makes sense for the source. Runner decides how to map those splits into its internal processing parallelism. In that sense does 'maxSourceParallism' directly influence 'desiredNumSplits'? How it works in : Streaming applications in Dataflow: Its 'desiredNumSplits' is based on max number of cores the jobs is configured (due to autoscaling, actually number of cores might be fewer). If the source returns more splits than suggested, I think Dataflow tries to run all of the splits in parallel (need to check if there is a limit). --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4340)*

Kenn, making the change to pass in the window, side input id, etc.. breaks an abstraction of trying to prevent details from leaking into the MultimapSideInput that it shouldn't have to worry about like the side input id, side input window that was mapped, etc...

It also changes the caching semantics since we'll want to cache encoding the window, side input id, ptransform id as much as possible and not pay encoding costs.

Code seems fine, and is certainly no worse than `CompletableFuture`. So go ahead and merge when ready, but maybe take it further afterwards.

Do you really want cancelation by either end to be the same method? I guess it seems like the new class has a similar problem to `CompletableFuture` that it exists in a liminal space between the interfaces intended for the consumer and producer of the data. It is (mis-)named and documented like it is for the consumer, but its API is for the producer. I think we are in territory addressed by this SO answer: [https://stackoverflow.com/questions/14541975/difference-between-future-and-promise](https://stackoverflow.com/a/28821051/949327)

"a future is a read-only container for a result that does not yet exist, while a promise can be written (normally only once). The Java 8 CompletableFuture and the Guava SettableFuture can be thought of as promises, because their value can be set ("completed"), but they also implement the Future interface, therefore there is no difference for the client."

There's lots of other guidance like "In Scala a Future object is created by an asynchronous computation or by a different Promise object. In C++ the situation is similar: the promise object is used by the producer and the future object by the consumer." and "\[`CompletableFuture`'s\] most useful feature is the unrelated chaining of processing steps."

Closing this in favor of a solution that fixes the dependency issue.

Ok, so the only real remaining problem is the queue swap that could cause the record loss. I don't know how to fix that yet so I propose to stick to the fixed-size queue with capacity enough for 1 or 2 shards. That solution is safe and only performance could be affected. We could come back to improving the performance if anyone complains. What do you think @jkff?

In fact, adjusting the queue size to the number of shards was just my assumption for scaling the performance. Actually the number of records is one of two factors that should be taken into consideration. The other one is the average record size. So to sum up, maybe adjusting the queue size doesn't matter that much?
